href="https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=http%3A%2F%2Fjason.mchu.com%2FZKP.ppt">slides
of Jason Chu</a> and the notes from Prof. Barak’s <a
href="http://www.cs.princeton.edu/courses/archive/fall07/cos433/lec15.pdf">lecture
at Princeton</a>.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>They both use a different
example of a simple ZK Proof than the one we had in the lecture, namely the
proof that an element in Zn* is a quadratic residue.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>You can see similarities, however, in the way
the two proofs are structured.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Moreover,
the intro and motivation and definition discussion are the same.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

two-party computation of any polynomial-time function.</span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span><span class=GramE>Oblivious Transfer
protocol.</span> <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.5in'><span style='font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";

See Prof. <a
href="https://eee.uci.edu/toolbox/dropbox/download.php/sjarecki_sec-comp.ppt?op=getfile&file=2791228"><span
class=SpellE>Kilian’s</span> lecture</a> on secure computation.<span

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.5in'><span style='font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";
mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin'>It shows and motivates the definition and goes
over Yao’s “garbled circuit” construction.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>Some motivation slides (from slide 6 to slide 12) are mostly about
multi-party version of the problem, while we considered only its two-party
version, but slide 10 gives is exactly the 2-party version so skim these if you
do not quite follow them and it mostly goes over the same material.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Except that it assumes knowledge of Oblivious
Transfer, which we explained and constructed <span class=GramE>using<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>ElGamal</span> encryption.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span><o:p></o:p></span></p>
